children: In this lesson, we dive deep into the structure of solution sets for linear systems, focusing on the powerful idea of **homogeneity** and its connection to **linear independence**. Youâ€™ll see how the solutions to **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{0} $** form a subspace â€” the **null space** â€” and how this shapes the solutions to non-homogeneous systems.
Weâ€™ll also define **linear independence** precisely and show how it determines whether solutions are unique.
By the end of this lesson, you will:

children.children: Understand the difference between **homogeneous** and **non-homogeneous** systems.
Describe the **null space** of a matrix as a subspace defined by **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{0} $**.
Recognize that solution sets of **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** are **translations** of the null space.
Define **linear independence** of vectors and test it using matrix rank.
Connect linear independence to the **uniqueness** of solutions.

The zero vector on the right-hand side guarantees **at least one solution**: the **trivial solution** **$ \vec{x} = \vec{0} $**.

children.children: **Trivial solution**: **$ \vec{x} = \vec{0} $** â€” always exists.
**Non-trivial solution**: Some **$ \vec{x} \neq \vec{0} $** such that **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{0} $**.

children: âœ… Non-trivial solutions exist **if and only if** the columns of **$ A $** are **linearly dependent**.
The existence of non-trivial solutions means some column can be written as a combination of the others.
2. The Null Space: A Solution Space
The set of all solutions to **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{0} $** is called the **null space** of **$ A $**, denoted **$ \text{Nul}(A) $**.
It is always a **subspace** of **$ \mathbb{R}^n $** (where **$ n $** is the number of variables), meaning:

children.children: It contains the zero vector.
It is closed under vector addition: if **$ \vec{u}, \vec{v} \in \text{Nul}(A) $**, then **$ \vec{u} + \vec{v} \in \text{Nul}(A) $**.
It is closed under scalar multiplication: if **$ \vec{u} \in \text{Nul}(A) $**, then **$ t\vec{u} \in \text{Nul}(A) $** for any scalar **$ t $**.

children: A set of vectors **$ \vec{v}_1, \vec{v}_2, \dots, \vec{v}_p $** is **linearly independent** if the **only** solution to:
is **$ c_1 = c_2 = \cdots = c_p = 0 $** â€” the **trivial** combination.
If thereâ€™s a **non-trivial** solution (some **$ c_i \neq 0 $**), the vectors are **linearly dependent**.

If there are **free variables** â†’ vectors are **dependent**.

children: Linear independence means no redundancy â€” every vector adds new direction.

children.children: The solution set of **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{0} $** is a **subspace**: the **null space**.
The solution set of **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** is a **translated null space** â€” not through the origin.
Linear independence means: **no vector is a linear combination of the others**.
Columns of **$ A $** independent **$\Leftrightarrow$** **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{0} $** has only trivial solution.
Uniqueness of solution to **$ A\vec{x} = \vec{b} $** depends entirely on linear independence.

children: This algebraic-geometric duality is the heart of linear algebra â€” and will be essential for understanding eigenvectors, orthogonality, and more.
